awd_titl_txt: PERSIST Promoting Engagement, Retention and Success in STEM Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at the University of California-Riverside will provide scholarships for low-income, talented students with demonstrated financial need pursuing bachelor's degrees in the sciences. In addition to scholarships, the program will provide academic and other support to increase the persistence of academically talented, low-income students.  Project efforts focus extensively on sophomores to facilitate transition to upper-level science coursework. The project has identified the sophomore year as a time when many capable students leave science majors. The results of this project will be applicable to other institutions seeking to increase retention of second-year science students. Scholarships and support for academically strong students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic vitality of California and the nation.

Progress has been made in identifying some of the factors which can help improve the success of undergraduate science students in the first year.  However, a challenge remains as a significant percentage of students do not persist in science majors beyond the end of their sophomore year. This project will focus on sophomores to facilitate upper division continuation at a time when many students leave science majors. The scholarships will decrease the need for low-income students to work part-time and thus increase their opportunities to be involved in second year undergraduate research and internships with industry. The academic support will include curricular and co-curricular activities such as research methodology, peer mentoring and career exploration workshops. The project will eliminate or reduce the need for low-income students to work part-time and increase students' aspirations towards further participation in STEM research and internship experiences.  An additional emphasis will be on talented students who begin in precalculus. These students were found to have lower graduation rates in STEM compared to students who are ready to take calculus in the first year.  Lower graduation rates are due in part to a need to pay extra tuition to catch up in mathematics and science courses the summer after the first year. By focusing on a time that is particularly important for undergraduate persistence in STEM and on a particular sample of students who have an even less likelihood of persisting, this program hopes to positively impact the trajectory of talented low-income students typically underrepresented in STEM fields. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community and help increase understanding of the attributes and practices of successful student scholarship and support programs.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
The overall problem addressed by this project is the issue of students not persisting in STEM majors, and instead switching to non-STEM majors or not completing their degrees in a timely manner.  Students from low-income backgrounds, first generation students, and minoritized populations are more likely to switch out of STEM degrees, which leads to a less diverse STEM workforce.

 

The hypothesis for this project was that financial support would allow low-income students who start with lower math placements (pre-calculus) to persist and graduate in a STEM major in a timely manner.  The PERSIST program paid students a stipend over the year and incorporated multiple interventions to mentor, educate, and engage students throughout the year. Students who were selected for the program were low income and/or first generation and matriculated to UCR in a College of Natural & Agricultural Science (CNAS) major with a low math placement (one of two pre-calculus levels or intermediate algebra). 

 

PERSIST program components:

- weekly meetings throughout the year with peer mentors and faculty

- stipends paid throughout the year

- career exposition workshop with CNAS alumni and the Career Center

- Keck Graduate Institute visits, meeting faculty and learning about science careers and pathways

- mentored research & professional development during the summer

- presenting summer research project in a symposium, and write final reports

- for students in the final cohort of PERSIST, a wet-lab bootcamp to gain lab skills

- for students in the final cohort of PERSIST, Agribusiness projects mentored by KGI and UCR faculty

 

The outcomes for students in the PERSIST program greatly exceeded the stated objectives for retention and graduation in STEM majors.  The students in the PERSIST cohorts were more likely than their classmates to continue in math and science majors, with nearly all participating students remaining in a CNAS major (96%).  Of the 73 students who participated in the program over 6 years, only 3 left UCR before graduating.   Of the remaining 70 students, all but three remained in a STEM major. 

 

The PERSIST students graduated at rates higher than other CNAS students, including students who are not low income or from marginalized backgrounds.  For example, 77% of the 2017 PERSIST cohort graduated in 4 years with a STEM major, and 75% of the 2018 PERSIST cohort completed STEM BS degrees within 4 years. These cohorts reached 92.3% and 100% graduation rates with STEM majors within 5 years.  For comparison, the success rate of second year low income CNAS students graduating with a CNAS major in 4 years was 45.9% (2017 cohort) and 50% (2018 cohort), with 53.6% and 58% completing within 5 years for the 2017 and 2018 cohorts. Thus, the PERSIST program participants had much higher success in graduating in a STEM degree than other CNAS students.

 

Interestingly, applicants to PERSIST who were not selected for the program were more successful in terms of STEM persistence (84%) and graduation than CNAS students overall, although a smaller proportion of the applicant group graduated with a STEM major as compared to the PERSIST group.  For example, the 2017 and 2018 cohorts (18 students total) reached a high of 56% of students graduating in STEM majors whereas all but one of the PERSIST students (24) from those cohorts graduated with STEM degrees. The unsuccessful applicants, like all CNAS students, would have had access to college and career workshops, but likely not a similar level of intense mentoring, added financial support, and other aspects of the PERSIST program.  

 

PERSIST did not impact the GPA of participating students; students’ cumulative GPA at graduation or the end of the project remained similar to their starting GPA.  

 

The external qualitative evaluation noted that participants who were interviewed felt that the PERSIST program had significant positive benefits for them and others in the program.  Quoting from the report, "Every student said that the program contributed significantly to their success, with the majority stating that the program was an essential/integral component to their success/that they would not be nearly as successful without the program."   The final evaluation report includes recommendations for key aspects of PERSIST that could be scalable and likely to provide significant benefits to students to promote successful graduation and careers in STEM fields. 


Last Modified: 02/10/2023
Modified by: Constance I Nugent
